aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident in Hermleigh, Texas
The accident occurred in Hermleigh, Texas.
The accident occurred on August 4, 2013, at 17:00 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Cessna 150D.
The defining event was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Instructional.
The accident number was CEN13CA485.
The aircraft registration was N4281U.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were no injuries in the accident.
The pilot held a helicopter rating.
The pilot was receiving flight instruction to add an airplane single engine land rating to his private pilot certificate.
The pilot was on a solo cross country flight.
The pilot had been inflight for about three hours when he became disoriented.
The pilot was unable to find an airport.
The pilot had a low fuel situation.
The pilot elected to make a precautionary off field landing to an unpaved road.
After touchdown, directional control of the aircraft was lost.
The aircraft impacted an embankment on the side of the road.
The impact resulted in substantial damage to the fuselage.
The impact resulted in substantial damage to both wings.
The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical malfunctions with the airplane.
The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical failures with the airplane.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot's improper positional awareness.
The pilot's improper positional awareness resulted in an off airport landing.
The pilot's improper positional awareness resulted in impact with terrain.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "lack of action" by the pilot as a finding.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "directional control - not attained/maintained" related to the aircraft as a finding.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Hermleigh, Texas

## Date & Time: 
August 4, 2013, 17:00 Local

## Aircraft:
Cessna 150D

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Instructional

## Accident Number:
CEN13CA485

## Registration:
N4281U

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

The pilot reported that he held a helicopter rating and he was receiving flight instruction to add an airplane single engine land rating to his private pilot certificate. He was on a solo cross country flight and had been inflight for about three hours when he became disoriented and was unable to find an airport. Because of his low fuel situation the pilot elected to make a precautionary off field landing to an unpaved road. After touchdown, directional control was lost and the airplane impacted an embankment on the side of the road resulting in substantial damage to the fuselage and both wings. The pilot reported no preaccident mechanical malfunctions or failures with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's improper positional awareness, which resulted in an off airport landing and impact with terrain.

## Findings

| | |
|-|-|
| Personnel issues | Lack of action - Pilot |
| Aircraft | Directional control - Not attained/maintained |

---
